awd_titl_txt: Conference: Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) Biennial Principal Investigator Workshop; Washington, DC; July 30-31, 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds a workshop to bring together Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) grantees and program managers from the National Science Foundation (NSF), the Department of Energy (DoE), the Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL), the Office of Naval Research (ONR), the US Army Combat Capabilities Development Command (DEVCOM), and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), and various other federal agencies with a stake in the MGI. The MGI was launched in 2011 to accelerate the discovery, design, development, and deployment of new materials, at a fraction of the cost, by harnessing the power of data and computational tools in concert with experiment. As NSF's response to the MGI, the Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) program seeks to foster collaborations between materials researchers with expertise in synthesis, experiment, theory, computation, and data science on highly iterative feedback loops in which experimental results directly inform theory and computation, and vice versa. This workshop brings together DMREF awardees with those supported by other federal agencies in order to discuss their challenges and successes; provide an assessment of the current status of the Initiative; and be a springboard to collaborative work leveraging rapid growth in data, data-driven AI/ML, and community-wide infrastructure development. 

A primary goal of this workshop is to assess the current status and opportunities for MGI across participating agencies. The following aims are pursued: 1) Accelerate materials research through data-driven approaches including artificial intelligence, machine learning, and natural language processing, 2) Transition fundamental research along the Materials Development Continuum, 3) Address educational and diversity issues, and 4) Promote collaboration among MGI PIs. The workshop will consist of overview talks of MGI-related activities at various federal agencies, technical presentations by the attendees, poster sessions, and breakout sessions on overarching topics. The overarching themes will be presented in a report for dissemination to the broader materials research community and the public. The program includes workgroups focused on workforce development where students and postdoctoral scholars are encouraged to attend and participate. Results from the workshop will be made available to the broader materials community and the public in the form of an electronic (PDF) Conference Proceeding booklet that will include abstracts from the posters and presentations. The workshop, which will be held in downtown Washington DC on July 30-31, 2024, follows a series of successful workshops, the latest being held in June 2022.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The 2024 Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) Principal Investigator Workshop, hosted by Johns Hopkins University on July 30-31 in Washington, DC, marked a significant milestone in advancing materials science and innovation. Bringing together nearly 300 participants—including faculty, students, postdocs, government representatives, and industry experts—the workshop aimed to evaluate progress, discuss grand challenges, and identify future opportunities within the framework set forth by the 2021 MGI Strategic Plan.

The intellectual merit of the workshop was rooted in its extensive discussions around five central themes: current progress in MGI programs, identifying grand challenges for materials innovation, the transformative role of artificial intelligence (AI) and autonomous laboratories, capturing and applying digital knowledge, and exploring upcoming opportunities tied to these challenges. Participants actively engaged through plenary sessions, panel discussions, and breakout groups, offering important perspectives and collaborative insights.

Significant intellectual contributions included presentations on the latest developments in AI-driven materials research, detailed updates from federal agencies, international efforts aligned with MGI goals, and important findings from recent national studies. Over 130 research posters and 55 oral presentations framed the intellectual dialogue by highlighting groundbreaking work and emerging areas of research across materials science.

Breakout sessions provided targeted, in-depth exploration of how materials research could directly address pressing societal challenges. Groups identified tangible targets and mapped critical needs across seven key areas:

  1. Protecting and Improving Human Health
  2. Delivering Resilient Energy
  3. Thriving in Extreme Environments
  4. Enhancing Structural Performance
  5. Protecting the Environment
  6. Propelling the Information and Communications Technology Revolution
  7. Advancing Critical and Emerging Technologies

These discussions focused on creating actionable ideas and laying the foundation for future MGI initiatives.

The broader impacts of the 2024 MGI PI Workshop are substantial, extending far beyond the immediate community of researchers. By uniting stakeholders across sectors and focused on the breadth of technical readiness levels of materials discovery, the workshop facilitated strategic connections among academia, government, and industry. Notably, the participation and engagement of students and early-career researchers—as full partners in the workshop—reinforced MGI’s commitment to developing future leaders in materials science. Additionally, the provision of travel awards enabled the inclusion of 19 promising students and postdocs to ensure wide perspective on discussions and outcomes.

Community engagement efforts at the workshop directly supported the strategic goal of accelerating materials research deployment through AI and digital knowledge management. This approach promises not only technological breakthroughs but also sustainable economic benefits across society.

Finally, the systematic documentation of workshop outcomes—including archived notes, presentations, and a forthcoming publication of proceedings—ensures ongoing accessibility and impact, enabling the broader materials science community to benefit from and build upon these valuable discussions.

Overall, the 2024 MGI PI Workshop successfully fulfilled its mission to advance national materials innovation infrastructure, harness materials data powerfully, and educate, train, and connect the materials research workforce for sustained future progress.


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Thao D Nguyen
